fullProgramDescription: The Physiological Science major is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the functions and processes that occur within living organisms. The program covers a broad range of topics, including the molecular, cellular, and systems levels of organization, and prepares students for careers in research, healthcare, and other related fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Physiological Science major at UCLA provides a comprehensive education in the functions and processes of living organisms, preparing students for careers in research, healthcare, and related fields.
classHighlights: The major core courses include Physiology 101-102 (Introduction to Human Physiology), which provide a foundational understanding of physiological processes. Students also take courses in Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, and Biophysics.
Additional required courses include Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience, Systems Neuroscience, and Physiology 107 (Physiological Systems Laboratory).
Students also complete coursework in Chemistry, Physics, and Mathematics, including Calculus and Statistics.
Upper-division courses in Physiological Science cover topics such as exercise physiology, cardiovascular physiology, and neurophysiology.
Electives allow students to explore specialized areas, such as neuroplasticity, endocrinology, and comparative physiology.
learningOutcomes: Understand the principles of human physiology at the molecular, cellular, and systems levels.
Apply knowledge of physiological processes to understand complex systems and disease states.
Analyze and interpret data from physiological experiments.
Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills to physiological problems.
additionalInformation: The Physiological Science major is designed to be completed in four years. Students are advised to consult with departmental advisors to ensure timely completion of major requirements.
